document.title: American Samoa English Language Arts Course Standards

4ED3785A29094C57AB93869AE73C8D5E.description: Compile a list of various sources (citations) used for a research report, using the APA (called references) or MLA (called works cited) style sheet

AD01E947B489487494AF9AB776982D2D.description: Find quotes or information from a book, journal, newspaper, and Internet site to put into an academic essay, and follow guidelines for citing sources (in-text citation) according to the MLA or APA style sheet

DBBF709BB84D4E85A8E5DD54D57C99AC.description: Include a chart and/or diagram in an essay or report, and document the source according to guidelines provided

08FF60600BA3472B8633FF5AF65DD64A.description: Format a Word document correctly (e.g., font, spacing, titles, margins, header) for an essay with a title page and for a report (e.g., for a business or technical purpose)

2F43F81576EF46A187AF3A60D329C3D6.description: Demonstrate a developing practice of organizing writing according to an identified purpose, academic or technical

A6F4295DA03948B192F10878438177AA.description: Revise and edit own writing, with the help of a peer and/or teacher

5727FA10CE8E4F598791B69421E4D6B3.description: Demonstrate proper use of commas with restrictive (no commas) and nonrestrictive (pair of commas) clauses and phrases

CD3888026E7C456986CDDAA99CE2A1C2.description: Demonstrate proper use of the semicolon, with and without a conjunctive adverb, to link two closely related independent clauses

37DFA810D2564B328624B8D9E83E882E.description: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing

D5D03DA7845F4600919799CDC1294980.description: Demonstrate knowledge and skill of combining sentences using subordinate conjunctions and relative pronouns

DF81845462CC45E08097C6EE82200898.description: Recognize three kinds of dependent clauses: adjective, adverb, and noun clauses, and demonstrate skill to use them

643D26100758422680ED1220B58FDEDE.description:
Recognize errors and make corrections to participial and prepositional phrases that have been
misplaced (dangling and misplaced modifiers)

DFCC0075633B489A93D04B94C51CF595.description: Demonstrate effective parallel structure in a PowerPoint presentation

F79E9A06E9AD48AE8418B7FC86C01238.description: Demonstrate an increasing command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking

D967F86CEE1544E28815FA1DCA9CD6CD.description: Students recognize and apply conventions of English in order to produce oral and written texts.

2419422C168143D4BDEFC46F7A352289.description: Distinguish among the connotations, or associated feelings/attitudes of words, with similar denotations, or literal definitions (e.g., assertive, aggressive, emphatic, confident, insistent, overbearing); create drawings or use dramatic expression to show meanings (e.g., caricatures; verbal and nonverbal expression)

389655A5E2174EE98289A4CB09F4B2E4.description: Use the relationship between particular words (e.g., conflict/dilemma; critique/critical; global/international/multinational) to make better connections between each of the words, and write sentences that clearly reveal the distinctions and connections

EB09DACEB44342FE85228088D7C26A8C.description: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., paradox, irony, literary, biblical, mythological allusions, or references) in context, and discuss examples in class

BF15E63895554BBAB00D21ED9EF47D48.description: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings

3D00C46C55CA4282905CA074BEA32454.description: Use word origin information in a dictionary to determine the derivations of selected words from a reading

228948E73F594225892DD9CC34B29746.description: Consult print/digital reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to find the pronunciation of a word, determine or clarify its precise meaning, or its part of speech

EAA52B65A0DD4C22866ECB50BDF6A1E7.description: Use common, grade-appropriate Greek or Latin affixes and roots as clues to meanings of recognizable and academic words (e.g., symbol, symbolic, symbolism, symmetry, symbiotic), and discuss with examples the value of knowing word parts

2C2AD4C15FE542B4AE9519603EF1E1CE.description: Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence or paragraph; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning of a word or phrase

1B2D7B1DD2394BFBA140981650FF4903.description: Apply various strategies to discover the meaning of unknown words and phrases and demonstrate academic readiness in gathering vocabulary knowledge of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases common at the college and career level

A8638383CC48415B9C386DF491735151.description: Students apply strategies to comprehend and utilize vocabulary appropriately in a variety of contexts: social, instructional, and academic.

F39D9DF8C1F548E4A8AC8177C8F31F1E.description: Contribute to a class website or blog that presents tips on “how to” organize and facilitate guest speakers and collegial discussion, and provide a chronological record of class experiences, personal reflections, and “quotable quotes”

A9BFC02AC3644CC2B0E00E94CA7B234D.description: Ask and respond to questions that relate the current discussion to broader themes or larger ideas; actively incorporate others into the discussion; and clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions

F63D167EEDB646838938B313A58892CE.description: Work with peers to set rules for collegial discussions and decision making (e.g., informal consensus, taking votes on key issues, presentation of alternate views); to set clear goals; establish boundaries (e.g., time limits, deadlines, turn-taking); and negotiate taking individual roles as needed (e.g., facilitator, recorder, time/task monitor, devil’s advocate)

219B5E9DCC5249B289BA5B2BF2048B1A.description: Come to discussions prepared, having read and researched the material under study, and explicitly draw on that preparation by referring to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well-reasoned exchange of ideas

C8496D1684BF4276B3A2E0A8120AA553.description: Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions with diverse partners— one-on-one, in groups, and teacher led—on relevant grade 12 topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas, and expressing own ideas clearly and convincingly

243F2CBF1EF44A3295417F4DFD5F81CA.description: Compare two speakers (on media, in the community, in class); use an evaluation tool (e.g., rubric, customized graphic organizer) to evaluate and critique speakers’ messages and approaches; and determine a best and worst example, and defend the choice

22322938BA794C6AA58F3DAA0BE4A518.description: Critique a well-known or recorded speech (e.g., political, motivational, educational) through an analysis of content, point of view, style, tone and purpose; share ideas in a panel discussion; and write about the speech

964BF22A1C244ACB93193C9C8F77A459.description: Identify examples of verbal and nonverbal choices a speaker uses to communicate effectively (e.g., rhetorical devices, cohesion, word choice, emphasis, tone, stance, emotionality)

2D5856CD986E4ABCBDCA72348BF0F4CF.description: Evaluate a speaker’s point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence and rhetoric, assessing the stance, premises, links among ideas, word choices, points of emphasis, and tone

16627D8F9CAB4714A38AA06A0330D46D.description: Listen to a formal “debate” (e.g., visit or watch a movie clip of a courtroom, government in session, town hall meeting, or local debate); take notes of main ideas and key supporting details (e.g., examples, reasons, evidence); discuss; and then write, to explore reflective responses

46C85BBA62FB4CA7A830C1F64294B271.description: Listen to grade-appropriate live or media presentations about various topics, and take notes to confirm comprehension and participate in discussions

3EBEA359D1CA4FE690E35A31032A3B5E.description: Students apply strategies for listening and collaborate with others to comprehend what is heard and spoken

F7693E8F3FF74847BE33CA95DA4A9A2E.description: Write and present three related two-voice dialogues about a local or international concern for three different situations: a news story, an informal conversation between friends and family, and a discussion in a formal academic or business meeting (e.g., controversial proposal for a change in the community, local environmental issue, world event or issue)

B30264BB842645748CCDC6398E24E8D1.description: Write a speech on a topic about “wisdom for life,” and deliver the speech, using appropriate style and formality, to two different audiences (e.g., a community group, a teacher panel, a parent group, another grade group, an employer, a team of peers)

396005B0FAF349E08E1B1C7F3F33204D.description: Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating a command of formal English when indicated or appropriate

8429969651F546C4B42E52F5EB0F052A.description: Debate on various local and national issues, and invite visitors (from the school or community) to watch and respond

F64F2359ECBB497194CBA91E6707459E.description: Participate in a class “town hall” meeting on a controversial local or school issue: prepare a speech to deliver a specific perspective on the issue, and be ready to respond to challenges by others

1F9791641310487394B877FAA96D5174.description: Present information on a range of formal and informal tasks by conveying a clear and distinct perspective, by providing a clear line of reasoning that addresses alternative or opposing perspectives, and by organizing carefully to suit the purpose and intended audience

A3754A0384164B06AD87E05D5EE70C2E.description: Students present their knowledge and ideas orally and comprehensibly.

D3A9D8A6CA554FB69BFFDC089F8A6650.description: Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the subject under investigation; write an outline for a presentation, and present it to the class; and write a (journal) reflection on the research done and on the usefulness and challenges of research in general

C328F5BF98BE49129C5AA8329B05B455.description: Create an annotated bibliography of four sources encountered during research (i.e., a 3–5 sentence summary of the content and/or usefulness of a resource)

3094921D0B5C4DB8B5BC9217A9B386CE.description: Gather information from primary resources (e.g., personal interviews, notes from a live speech), and secondary resources (e.g., print and media materials), and record the source information according to a style sheet (e.g., MLA) in a reference list

090BEEC249D94F3DB0D10DCD989203E5.description: Select a topic of national or international interest to do a research project, narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate, and synthesize multiple sources on the subject

23E028740B7E4BB3A6F4450A258EF964.description: Conduct short, as well as more sustained research projects, to answer a question (including a self- generated question) or solve a problem, using multiple sources

34E78D67A7D643AFB4A6C206DE6E48CE.description: Students research to build and present knowledge in writing.

215322654F77406F9FD2E4E71BCC8F76.description: Use the computer to find information for selected writing assignments, and use technology to present information (e.g., word process essays; prepare PowerPoint presentations that include graphs and charts; create a class blog on a topic)

DC4E17B1D8D54825BDDB5AD21B76BDFE.description: Use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

D5C9F8CB67F34777B5056D62624B824F.description: Peer edit for others, and respond to editing done by peers (i.e., read each other’s work in order to ask questions and offer suggestions for change and improvement)

34508375824D4B4C90B72D9DB7105B0A.description: Use the writing process to accomplish a task on a given topic, including prewriting activities and multiple drafts with revisions and edits

76F4A2A695C94DF5A4817242AC5FF6DE.description: Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

199A7D24724C4C939009D954F80749CE.description: Demonstrate proper format (e.g., titles and headers, spacing, punctuation, referencing and citing resources)

8C3522D23680429D9DAD0695C1E23D5D.description: Write texts that each have an appropriate form or “shape” (i.e., an introduction, thesis, body, and conclusion); produce strong topic sentences and thesis statements that control the writing; include only details, reasons, and examples that support the main idea (i.e., omit irrelevant information or examples); and organize the ideas to accomplish unity, fluency, and cohesion

FD7C575B3E704B169EC6EA5F560A98E1.description: Choose a form and format that suits the tasks, purposes, and audiences (e.g., narrative, essay, report, online article, informational text with visual representations)

FC68506AC6B2434C9C9DE8B2340584DD.description: Produce clear and coherent writings in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

F29E2BB303724F119E8931815FB9907F.description: Students use various processes to produce and distribute a wide range of their writing.

A0223A46E4E345F99E1444424D85BC21.description: Talk and write about the experience of being a story writer, sharing the process, the challenges, the expected effects, and the overall meaning/purpose

0263E471DD5B4771B910494A77D4135D.description: Write a narrative, working individually, from a group-developed story outline; develop a clear plot line and suitable story elements (i.e., specific details for setting, characterization, and plot development) using narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, and reflection; and do an oral reading of excerpts or the complete narrative

B6F1DE0FC724491C99F40E62A6CC6F94.description: Identify a real or believable experience of paradox or dilemma, and, in a group, construct a skeleton story with conflict and action, suitable characters, and potential setting and tone

4225B91AC06D4DE09D8C18E442DD9225.description: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective techniques, well- chosen details, and well-structured event sequences

844C3191BE294C1F92B2388344A1BAA3.description: Revise writing, paying attention to format (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures; tables), and multimedia as required, as well as conventions of standard grammar and usage

004ABC32B9CE4F70B7E2B7E0A7E2E4C0.description: Review and rewrite to use appropriate and varied transitions and syntax to link the major sections of the text, to create cohesion, and to clarify the relationships among complex ideas and concepts; select precise language, domain-specific vocabulary, and techniques (e.g., metaphor, simile, imagery, analogy) to manage the topic

50EC08E06B2945D781CCE47B42536C57.description: Construct an essay that has unity of thought, including an introduction; a “hook” and thesis statement; a body that supports the thesis with relevant ideas; concepts and information; and a conclusion

F81491A128B946CAA6AEE689B72AC9C1.description: Write essays that define and explain concepts from grade 12 content (e.g., terminology related to literature, science, mathematics, social studies), and develop the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to an identified audience

1E5C4E27A0F14FCCB34D0DB8FDE64FBA.description: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection and organization of content

67268A5F66E54CE6B2A1DC1E29CEB95F.description: Modify the essay, as required, to ensure that transition words and phrases (e.g., adverbs like therefore, on the other hand, consequently) and conjunctions (so, but, because, although, if...then) make clear the relationships between claim(s) and reasons and between claim(s) and counterclaims

7229DE4F3F0E465AB2F93CA9F9F656C5.description: Demonstrate the ability to establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions for writing argument

77D293737E734BA08045525600EC724E.description: Organize and write an argument essay that introduces a clearly stated claim (thesis), establishes the reason for the claim, gives knowledgeable support, recognizes an opposing claim, and provides a concluding paragraph that follows from and supports the argument

3EB44FB62A02452DBA0C01F8686EFEFF.description: Develop two opposing claims, supplying the most relevant evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner that anticipates the audience’s knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases; distinguish one to be the claim and the other the counterclaim

6A2C82023EE64D4F9565BB00EFF8B786.description: Write arguments to support claims, using valid reasoning and sufficient relevant evidence

6694A2527E20414EA0CB50D9ADC761CF.description: Students apply their knowledge of text types and purposes.

BD06E8EF5EB64D3D8FB2D571365B512F.description: Use understanding of Samoan culture and tradition as an approach in analyzing a non-Pacific story, drama, or poem; use technology to make a presentation

487F50F1087E41CEA036988939819384.description: Compare a print text (story, drama, poem) with a media presentation (e.g., live or recorded reading, play, or film), and interpret the authors’ purposes, meanings, and attitudes and make observations about how the texts are similar and different; diagram/chart the information, and then talk and write about it

6CA3567E4DE44A08AD60D0D36D128FB3.description: Analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem evaluating how each version interprets the source text

22AD28B103954F59AD4B6CECE52191BA.description: Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different media (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea, and write a composition that expresses an opinion

EE7DE275B2D84B86A458181616BDBFBC.description: Examine two versions of the same story or informational text (e.g., story or script made into a drama; a text made into a documentary), and determine if it stays faithful to, or departs from, the original; discuss opinions

EED4C534D5F445198C83B5996457F4A9.description: Investigate multiple sources of information presented in different text forms, including media, and compare the way each approaches information, addresses a question, and/or solves a problem

69D01F83BE3644C19226670491D121E6.description: Students integrate knowledge to make meaningful connections between ideas in diverse texts.

DD7F4BCC651D4BDCB853A267FB8D8E48.description: Use the claim to create a statement for debate, and prepare and participate in a class debate

D82B3E9175F549C0A5699FC77AE87009.description: Use a graphic organizer to diagram the flow of all claims and support in a text, explain how the structure and language are used to present the argument, and critique whether or not the argument is clear and convincing

7818C7A93F5042FD9CD0A6255CA4B461.description: Analyze, with support, an author’s argument: Identify the claim statement and the key supporting points, identify any counter claim(s), and write a personal response

BDBA17AC9E7F4AED9CA5E7A70E18D479.description: Analyze arguments in grade-level texts, and evaluate the effectiveness of the structure an author uses in his or her exposition or argument, including whether or not the structure makes points clear, convincing, and engaging

1A1512AE23A24AC98BA26A08F518BDAE.description: Examine expository text; identify words in various textbooks that may have differing denotative and connotative meanings related to genre (e.g., a technical word in science or math having a different [specialized] meaning or use in literature or social studies); and create a “dictionary entry” for two or more of the words, using drawings and explanations

7CAE795759E84610B62E4D6E7AF296E8.description: Analyze specific words and phrases in a text that an author chooses to create particular impressions and tensions, explore an example of irony, and write a personal response to that example

F45D8F8DF4564BD28E8710C46F8F039D.description: Use context clues to determine the meanings of unknown words and/or phrases in a text; explore examples of imagery, metaphor, hyperbole, and paradox; and discuss how these contribute to the impact of the text

526C1BD4ABB9497A9898E56511086A19.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases, including figurative and connotative meanings, as they are used in various texts and media, and analyze the effect of specific word choices on attitude and tone

114851D52C084460BC0C25C5334E7E0B.description: Students investigate the craft and structure of a variety of texts.

6322D8F8DFDE4605ADC800ED0EC651EA.description: Examine two or more characters, the plot development, and key details of a literary text in order to analyze and explain dynamic relationships among these elements; i.e., make meaningful connections between the elements (e.g., how two characters impact one another; how the atmosphere affects the key characters; how the atmosphere reflects the conflict and highlights the plot development)

6C602BE6FB824A9AB19E904925064735.description: Examine a set of ideas and selected literary elements, and analyze how specific individuals, ideas, or events interact and develop over the course of the text

BEBBD3B947754EC7A0A828E6FD82C550.description: Compare central ideas and themes in multiple texts, exploring similarities to identify whether or not the theme is universal, and participate in a panel discussion

773733D3D08C4658AAAFF5934A23A680.description: Identify the theme of a selected text, discuss what it reveals about human nature, and write a theme statement (summary)

0F80C1483B5E433DA560552C474E665E.description: Identify central idea(s) in a text, examine how the idea is developed in the text, and explain in writing

931D5E4938C04B56A9F94B1008C3F50B.description: Determine central ideas and themes in grade-level texts; analyze development over the course of each text, including how they interact and build on one another; and provide a summary of the text

544580DEF1794639A6391705AC2D5D2F.description: Maintain a journal to record reflections about the readings through the year, relating them to personal life experiences

0210C45F8A874F6A8C9B3A37D9662E07.description: Examine literary and expository texts; identify examples of information that are stated explicitly and implicitly; use a graphic organizer to record observations and/or comparisons; and explain, with reasons for questioning or agreeing/disagreeing with selected information

3E2572463D1B4363AF3E568B491082C0.description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly and what the text infers, including determining where the text leaves matters uncertain

E7DD40A63838415692C46D3577B5C17A.description: Students inquire about and comprehend key ideas and details in a variety of texts.
